book.description: THE EPISTLE OF PAUL TO THE GALATIANS
book.info: Approximately A.D. 54, during Paul's second ministry journey, after traveling through Galatia and arriving in Corinth ([link]Acts 18:1[/link], [link]11[/link]).
Corinth, while Paul was there for a year and a half ([link]Acts 18:1-11[/link]).
book.subject: Christ Replacing the Law and Being versus Religion and Tradition

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Paul, an [xref]b[/xref]apostle ([note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]not from men nor through man but [xref]d[/xref]through Jesus Christ and God the Father, who [note]3[/note][xref]e[/xref]raised Him from the dead),
verse.note: The books of Galatians, Ephesians, Philippians, and Colossians form a cluster of Epistles that make up the heart of the divine revelation in the New Testament. The essential subject of these four books is Christ and the church. Galatians reveals that Christ is versus religion with its law; Ephesians reveals the church as the Body of Christ; Philippians concerns the experience, the living out, of Christ; and Colossians unveils the all-inclusive and all-extensive Christ as the Head of the Body.

The purpose of this book is to cause its receivers to know that the gospel preached by the apostle Paul was not from man's teaching ([link]vv. 11-12[/link]) but from God's revelation. Hence, in the very opening of this book Paul emphasized that he became an apostle not from men nor through man but through Christ and God.

The law dealt with man as the old creation, whereas the gospel makes man the new creation in resurrection. God made Paul an apostle not by the law according to his natural man in the old creation but through the resurrection of Christ according to his regenerated man in the new creation. Hence, Paul did not say here, "God the Father, who gave the law through Moses," but "God the Father, who raised Him [Christ] from the dead." God's New Testament economy is not with men in the old creation but with men in the new creation through the resurrection of Christ.

verse.text: And all the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]brothers who are with me, to the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]churches of [xref]c[/xref]Galatia:
verse.note: The apostle considered all the brothers who were with him co-writers that they might be a testimony and a confirmation of what he wrote in this Epistle.

Galatia was a province of the ancient Roman Empire. Through Paul's preaching ministry, churches were established in a number of cities in that province. Hence, [i]churches,[/i] not [i]church,[/i] was used when the apostle referred to the churches in Galatia collectively.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Grace to you and [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]peace from God [xref]c[/xref]our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ,
verse.note: See notes [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Eph. 1[/link] and [link]7[sup]2[/sup] in Rom. 1[/link].
See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Eph. 1[/link].

verse.text: Who [xref]a[/xref]gave Himself for our [xref]b[/xref]sins that He might [note]1[/note]rescue us out of the present evil [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]age according to the [xref]d[/xref]will of our God and Father,
verse.note: Lit., pluck us out of, draw us out of, extricate us from.

An age is a part of the world, which is the satanic system (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Eph. 2[/link]). According to the context of this book, the present evil age here refers to the religious world, the religious course of the world, the Jewish religion. This is confirmed by [link]6:14-15[/link], where circumcision is considered a part of the world — the religious world, which to the apostle Paul was crucified. Here the apostle emphasized that the purpose of Christ's giving Himself for our sins was to rescue us, to pluck us, out of the Jewish religion, the present evil age. This is to release God's chosen people from the custody of the law ([link]3:23[/link]), to bring them out of the sheepfold ([link]John 10:1[/link], [link]3[/link]), according to the will of God. Thus, in his opening word Paul indicated what he was going to deal with: he wanted to rescue the churches, which were distracted by Judaism with its law, and bring them back to the grace of the gospel.

verse.text: To whom be the [xref]a[/xref]glory forever and ever. Amen.

I marvel that you are so quickly [note]1[/note]removing from Him who has [xref]a[/xref]called you [note]2[/note]in the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]grace of Christ to a [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]different gospel,
verse.note: Here Paul came to his subject. Because the churches in Galatia were deserting the grace of Christ and backsliding to the observance of the law, Paul was burdened to write this Epistle.
Or, by.
The grace of Christ is the Triune God — the Father, the Son, and the Spirit — processed to become our enjoyment. This grace is versus the law of Moses ([link]John 1:17[/link] and note 1).

This was the Judaic observance of the law. Paul's gospel, which is outside the Judaic law, includes all the major items of the four Gospels. Moreover, it covers many more items so that the revelation of the word of God in the New Testament might be completed ([link]Col. 1:25[/link]) with crucial items such as Christ in the believers as the hope of glory ([link]Col. 1:27[/link]); the Spirit of God as a seal and a pledge ([link]Eph. 1:13-14[/link]); God's Son being revealed in us ([link]v. 16[/link]), being formed in us ([link]4:19[/link]), making His home in us ([link]Eph. 3:17[/link]), and filling us unto all the fullness of God ([link]Eph. 3:19[/link]); and Christ as the mystery of God ([link]Col. 2:2[/link]) and as the One in whom the fullness of the Godhead dwells bodily ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]). The focal point of Paul's gospel is that the Son of God, God's anointed One (the Christ), has entered into our being to be our life today ([link]Col. 3:4[/link]) and our glory in the future ([link]Col. 1:27[/link]) that we may be the members ([link]Rom. 12:5[/link]) of the Body of Christ ([link]Eph. 4:16[/link]), of which Christ is the Head ([link]Eph. 4:15[/link]).

verse.text: Which is [note]1[/note]not another [i]gospel,[/i] only there are [note]2[/note]some who [xref]a[/xref]trouble you and desire to [note]3[/note]pervert the gospel of Christ.
verse.note: The observance of the law could never be a gospel that could set sinners free from the bondage of the law and bring them into the enjoyment of God; it could only keep them as slaves under the bondage of the law, entangling them with the yoke of slavery of the law ([link]5:1[/link]).
The Judaizers, whom the apostle Paul considered false brothers ([link]2:4[/link]).
The Judaizers troubled the churches by perverting, distorting, the gospel of Christ, thus misleading the believers into going back to the law of Moses.

verse.text: But if even we or an [xref]a[/xref]angel out of heaven should announce to you a gospel beyond that which we have announced to you, let him be [xref]b[/xref]accursed.
As we have said before, now also I say again, If anyone announces to you a gospel beyond that which you have received, let him be accursed.

For am I now [note]1[/note]trying to win the assent of men or of God? Or am I seeking to [xref]a[/xref]please men? If I were still trying to please men, I would not be a [xref]b[/xref]slave of Christ.
verse.note: Or, persuading men or God; seeking to conciliate, to satisfy, men or God.

verse.text: For I make known to you, [xref]a[/xref]brothers, [i]concerning[/i] the [xref]b[/xref]gospel announced by me, that it is [xref]c[/xref]not according to man.
For [note]1[/note]neither did I receive [i]it[/i] from man, nor was I taught it, but I [xref]a[/xref]received it through a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]revelation by Jesus Christ.
verse.note: [i]Neither[/i]...from man corresponds with [i]not from men[/i] in [link]v. 1[/link].
The revelation given to the apostle Paul by the Lord Jesus Christ concerning the gospel.

verse.text: For you have heard of my manner of life [xref]a[/xref]formerly in [note]1[/note]Judaism, that I [xref]b[/xref]persecuted the [xref]c[/xref]church of God excessively and [xref]d[/xref]ravaged it.
verse.note: I.e., the Jewish religion, which is in contrast to the Son of God and the church ([link]vv. 13-16[/link]).

verse.text: And I [xref]a[/xref]advanced in Judaism beyond many contemporaries in my race, being more abundantly a [xref]b[/xref]zealot for the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]traditions of my [xref]d[/xref]fathers.
verse.note: Traditions in the sect of the Pharisees, of which Paul was a member. He called himself "a Pharisee, a son of Pharisees" ([link]Acts 23:6[/link]). The Jewish religion was composed not only of the God-given law and its rituals but also of manmade traditions.

verse.text: But when it [xref]a[/xref]pleased God, who [note]1[/note]set me apart [note]2[/note]from my mother's [xref]b[/xref]womb and [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]called me through His [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]grace,
verse.note: I.e., designated or distinguished for a purpose.
I.e., before he was born.
After he was born, at his conversion.
Paul was called to be an apostle through the grace of Christ, not through the law announced by Moses.

verse.text: To [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]reveal His [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Son [note]3[/note]in me that I might announce [note]4[/note]Him as the gospel among the [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]Gentiles, immediately I did [note]6[/note]not confer with [note]7[/note][xref]d[/xref]flesh and blood,
verse.note: Not to teach but to unveil, to give a vision of, to show.

The Son of God, as the embodiment and expression of God the Father ([link]John 1:18[/link]; [link]14:9-11[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:3[/link]), is life to us ([link]John 10:10[/link]; [link]1 John 5:12[/link]; [link]Col. 3:4[/link]). God's heart's desire is to reveal His Son in us that we may know Him, receive Him as our life ([link]John 17:3[/link]; [link]3:16[/link]), and become the sons of God ([link]John 1:12[/link]; [link]Gal. 4:5-6[/link]). As the Son of the living God ([link]Matt. 16:16[/link]), He is far superior to Judaism and its traditions ([link]vv. 13-14[/link]). The Judaizers had bewitched the Galatians into considering that the ordinances of the law were above the Son of the living God. Hence, in the opening of this Epistle the apostle testified that he had been deeply involved and had become far advanced in the realm of Judaism, but that God had rescued him out of that course of the world, which was evil in God's eyes, by revealing His Son in him. In his experience he realized that there was no comparison between the Son of the living God and Judaism with its dead traditions handed down from his forefathers.

God's revealing of His Son to us is in us; it is not outward but inward, not by an outward vision but by an inward seeing. It is not an objective revelation but a subjective one.[br][br]God made the apostle Paul a minister of Christ by setting him apart, calling him ([link]v. 15[/link]), and revealing His Son in him.
The apostle Paul did not preach the law but announced Christ, the Son of God, as the gospel; he announced not merely the doctrine concerning Him but the living person Himself.
The heathen Gentiles.
This confirms that the apostle did not receive the gospel from man ([link]v. 12[/link]).
I.e., man, composed of flesh and blood.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Neither did I go up to Jerusalem to those who were apostles before me, but I went away to [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Arabia and again returned to [xref]c[/xref]Damascus.
verse.note: It is difficult to trace where in Arabia Paul went and how long he stayed there after his conversion. However, the place must have been away from the Christians, and the time of his stay there must not have been short. His purpose in referring to his stay in Arabia was to testify that he did not receive the gospel from man ([link]v. 12[/link]). In Arabia he must have received some revelation concerning the gospel directly from the Lord.

verse.text: Then after three years I went up to [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem to [note]1[/note]visit [xref]b[/xref]Cephas, and I remained with him fifteen days.
verse.note: The Greek word implies to visit in order to become acquainted with.

verse.text: But I saw none of the other apostles [note]1[/note]except [xref]a[/xref]James, the brother of the Lord.
verse.note: This indicates that James, the brother of the Lord, and Cephas ([link]v. 18[/link]), who was Peter, were at that time the leading ones among the apostles.

verse.text: Now concerning the things which I am writing to you, behold, before God, I am [xref]a[/xref]not lying.
Then I went into the regions of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Syria and [xref]b[/xref]Cilicia.
verse.note: Arabia ([link]v. 17[/link]), Syria, and Cilicia were all regions of the Gentile world. By mentioning his journeys to all these places, Paul testified that the revelation he received concerning the gospel was not from any men, that is, from any Christians, who at that time were mainly in Judea ([link]v. 22[/link]).

verse.text: Yet I was still [note]1[/note]unknown by face to the [xref]a[/xref]churches of Judea, which are [xref]b[/xref]in Christ.
verse.note: Paul said this to strengthen the point that he did not receive the gospel from any who were believers in Christ before him.

verse.text: But they [note]1[/note]only heard [i]this:[/i] He who was formerly [xref]a[/xref]persecuting us is now announcing as the gospel the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]faith which formerly he [xref]c[/xref]ravaged.
verse.note: The churches, which included all the believers in Christ in Judea, only heard the news of Paul's conversion and glorified God because of him. They had nothing to do with his receiving the revelation concerning the gospel.

The faith here and in all the verses of reference 23[sup]b[/sup] implies our believing in Christ, taking His person and His redemptive work as the object of our faith. The faith, replacing the law, by which God dealt with people in the Old Testament, became the principle by which God deals with people in the New Testament. This faith characterizes the believers in Christ and distinguishes them from the keepers of law. This is the main emphasis of this book. The law of the Old Testament stresses letters and ordinances, whereas the faith of the New Testament emphasizes the Spirit and life.

verse.text: And they [xref]a[/xref]glorified God because of me.
Then [note]1[/note]after a period of fourteen years I [xref]a[/xref]went up again to Jerusalem with [xref]b[/xref]Barnabas, taking [xref]c[/xref]Titus with [i]me[/i] also.
verse.note: As recorded in [link]Acts 15[/link], this was after a number of churches had been raised up in the Gentile world through Paul's ministry (see [link]Acts 13-14[/link]). This indicates that Paul's preaching of the gospel to raise up the Gentile churches had nothing to do with the believers in Jerusalem and Judea.

verse.text: And I went up according to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]revelation, and I laid before them the gospel which I proclaim among the [xref]b[/xref]Gentiles, but privately to those who were of [xref]c[/xref]repute, [xref]d[/xref]lest perhaps I should be [xref]e[/xref]running, or had run, in vain.
verse.note: Not only Paul's gospel but even his going up to Jerusalem were according to the Lord's revelation, not according to any organization or system. Paul's move and activity were according to the Lord's instant leading. This again indicates that his preaching of the gospel was not according to man's teaching but according to the Lord's direct revelation.

verse.text: But [note]1[/note]not even Titus, who was with me, though he is a Greek, was compelled to be [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]circumcised;
verse.note: This indicates that in his move for the Lord's testimony, Paul did not care for the observance of the law.

Judaism was built upon the God-given law with its three pillars: circumcision, the Sabbath, and the holy dietary regulations. All three were ordained by God ([link]Gen. 17:9-14[/link]; [link]Exo. 20:8-11[/link]; [link]Lev. 11[/link]) as shadows of things to come ([link]Col. 2:16-17[/link]). Circumcision was a shadow of the crucifixion of Christ in its putting off of the flesh, as signified in baptism ([link]Col. 2:11-12[/link]). The Sabbath was a type of Christ as the rest for His people ([link]Matt. 11:28-30[/link]). The holy diet symbolized persons who are clean and persons who are unclean, those whom God's holy people should contact and those they should not contact ([link]Acts 10:11-16[/link], [link]34-35[/link]). Once Christ had come, all these shadows should have been terminated. Hence, the observance of the Sabbath was abolished by the Lord Jesus in His ministry ([link]Matt. 12:1-12[/link]), the holy dietary regulations were annulled by the Spirit in Peter's ministry ([link]Acts 10:9-20[/link]), and circumcision was counted as nothing in the revelation received by Paul in his ministry ([link]5:6[/link]; [link]6:15[/link]). Furthermore, the law, the base of Judaism, has been terminated and replaced by Christ ([link]Rom. 10:4[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:16[/link]). Thus, Judaism in its entirety is finished.

verse.text: And [i]this,[/i] because of the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]false brothers, brought in [xref]b[/xref]secretly, who stole in to spy out our [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]freedom which we have in Christ Jesus, that they might bring us into [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]slavery.
verse.note: The Judaizers, who perverted the gospel of Christ by secretly bringing the observances of the law into the church and troubled the genuine brothers in Christ ([link]1:7[/link]).

Freedom from the bondage of the law. This freedom in Christ Jesus includes (1) release from the bondage of the law, implying liberation from obligation to the law and its ordinances, practices, and regulations; (2) full satisfaction, with a rich, supporting supply; (3) the enjoyment of true rest, without being under the heavy burden to keep the law; and (4) the full enjoyment of the living Christ.
Slavery under the law.

verse.text: To them we yielded with the subjection [i]demanded[/i] not even for an hour, that the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]truth of the gospel might remain with you.
verse.note: Not the doctrine or the teaching of the gospel but the reality of the gospel.

verse.text: But from those who were [xref]a[/xref]reputed to be something — whatever they were makes no difference to me; God does [xref]b[/xref]not accept man's person; for to me those who were of repute added nothing.
But on the contrary, seeing that I had been [xref]a[/xref]entrusted with the gospel to the [xref]b[/xref]uncircumcision, even as [xref]c[/xref]Peter [i]with the gospel[/i] to the circumcision,
(For He who operated in Peter for the [xref]a[/xref]apostleship to the circumcision operated also in me for the [xref]b[/xref]Gentiles),

And perceiving the [xref]a[/xref]grace given to me, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]James and [xref]c[/xref]Cephas and [xref]d[/xref]John, who were [xref]e[/xref]reputed to be [xref]f[/xref]pillars, gave to me and to [xref]g[/xref]Barnabas the right [xref]h[/xref]hand of [xref]i[/xref]fellowship that we [i]should go[/i] to the Gentiles, and they, to the circumcision.
verse.note: When the apostles were listed, Peter was usually mentioned first ([link]Matt. 10:2[/link]; [link]Mark 3:16[/link]; [link]Luke 6:14[/link]; [link]Acts 1:13[/link]). Here, however, James was mentioned first. This indicates that at that time Peter was not the foremost leading one in the church; rather, it was James, the brother of the Lord ([link]1:19[/link]). This is confirmed by [link]Acts 15:13-21[/link], where James, not Peter, was the authority who gave the final, decisive word in the conference held in Jerusalem. It must have been because of Peter's weakness in not holding the truth of the gospel, as illustrated by Paul in [link book="Gal." chapter="2"]vv. 11-14[/link], that James came to the forefront to take the lead among the apostles. Hence, both in [link]v. 12[/link] and in [link]Acts 21:18[/link] James was considered the representative of the church in Jerusalem and of the apostles. This is strong proof that Peter was not always the foremost leader in the church. Furthermore, this implies that leadership in the church is not organizational and perpetual; rather, it is spiritual and fluctuates according to the spiritual condition of the leading ones. This strongly rebuts Catholicism in its assertion that Peter was the only successor of Christ in the administration of the church.

verse.text: Only [i]they requested[/i] that we remember the [xref]a[/xref]poor, which very thing I [xref]b[/xref]was also eager to do.
But when [xref]a[/xref]Cephas came to [xref]b[/xref]Antioch, I opposed him to [i]his[/i] face because he stood condemned.

For before some came [note]1[/note]from [xref]a[/xref]James, he [note]2[/note]continually [xref]b[/xref]ate with the Gentiles; but when they came, he began to shrink back and separate himself, [note]3[/note]fearing those of the [xref]c[/xref]circumcision.
verse.note: I.e., from the church in Jerusalem. This is another indication that at that time James, not Peter, was the first among the apostles in Jerusalem.
This was contrary to the customary practice of the Jews in their keeping of the observances of the law.

This proves that at that time Peter was very weak in the pure Christian faith. In [link]Acts 10[/link] he had received an exceedingly clear vision from the heavens concerning fellowship with the Gentiles, and he took the lead to practice it. What weakness and backsliding to shrink from eating with Gentile believers out of fear of those of the circumcision! It is no wonder that he lost the leadership among the apostles.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]rest of the Jews also joined him in this [note]2[/note]hypocrisy, so that even [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]Barnabas was carried away in their hypocrisy.
verse.note: When the leading one backslid, the rest easily followed.
That Peter, the leading apostle, practiced hypocrisy in relation to the truth of the gospel is almost incredible.

Barnabas participated in Paul's first ministry journey to preach the gospel to the Gentiles and to raise up the Gentile churches. Even one who had so much fellowship with the Gentile believers was carried away in Peter's hypocrisy. What a negative influence Peter exerted on others! Surely he deserved to lose his leadership.

verse.text: But when I saw that they were not [note]1[/note]walking in a [xref]a[/xref]straightforward way in relation to the [xref]b[/xref]truth of the gospel, I said to [xref]c[/xref]Cephas [xref]d[/xref]before [i]them[/i] all, If you, being a Jew, [note]2[/note][xref]e[/xref]live like the Gentiles and not like the Jews, how is it that you compel the Gentiles to [note]3[/note][xref]f[/xref]live like the Jews?
verse.note: Lit., walking straight-footedly.
I.e., eat, live, and fellowship with the Gentiles.
Lit., Judaize; i.e., live like the Jews, not eating or fellowshipping with the Gentiles.

verse.text: We are [xref]a[/xref]Jews by nature and not [xref]b[/xref]sinners from among the Gentiles;

And knowing that a man is not justified out of works of [xref]a[/xref]law, but through [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]faith in Jesus Christ, we also have believed into Christ Jesus that we might be justified out of faith in Christ and not out of the works of law, because out of the works of law [xref]c[/xref]no [note]2[/note]flesh will be justified.
verse.note: Lit., faith of Jesus Christ. See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in Rom. 3[/link]. [i]Faith in Jesus Christ[/i] denotes an organic union with Him through believing. This is related to the believers' appreciation of the person of the Son of God as the most precious One. The believers are infused with the preciousness of Christ through the gospel preached to them. This Christ becomes in them the faith by which they believe and the capacity to believe through their appreciation of Him. This faith creates an organic union in which they and Christ are one.
[i]Flesh[/i] here denotes fallen man, who has become flesh ([link]Gen. 6:3[/link]). No fallen man will be justified out of the works of law.

verse.text: But if, while seeking to be justified in Christ, we ourselves also have been found [xref]a[/xref]sinners, is then Christ a [note]1[/note]minister of sin? [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Absolutely not!
verse.note: One who ministers sin to people, or who serves sin to people.
Lit., May it not happen! So throughout the Epistle.

verse.text: For if I [note]1[/note]build again the things which I have [note]2[/note]destroyed, I prove myself to be a transgressor.
verse.note: I.e., return to Judaism. This refers to Peter's returning to the Judaic observance of not eating with Gentiles.
I.e., counted loss, counted as dung ([link]Phil. 3:7-8[/link]). Referring to Peter's abandoning of the Judaistic practice of not eating with the Gentiles.

verse.text: For I [note]1[/note]through law have [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]died to law that I might [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]live to God.
verse.note: The law requires us, as sinners, to die, and according to that requirement Christ died for us and with us. Hence, through law we have died in Christ and with Christ.
I.e., the obligation under the law, the relationship to the law, was terminated.
I.e., be obligated to God in the divine life. In Christ's death our relationship with the law has been terminated; in His resurrection we are responsible to God in the resurrection life.

verse.text: I am [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]crucified with Christ; and [i]it is[/i] [note]2[/note]no longer I [i]who[/i] live, but [i]it is[/i] [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]Christ [i]who[/i] lives in me; and the [note]4[/note][i]life[/i] which I now live in the flesh I [xref]c[/xref]live in [note]5[/note]faith, the [xref]d[/xref][i]faith[/i] [note]6[/note]of the [note]7[/note]Son of God, who [note]8[/note][xref]e[/xref]loved me and [xref]f[/xref]gave Himself up for me.
verse.note: This explains how it is that through law we have died to law. When Christ was crucified, according to God's economy we were included in Him. This is an accomplished fact.

[i]No longer I[/i] does not indicate an exchanged life, a life in which Christ comes in and we go out, for later in this verse Paul said, "I live." As regenerated people, we have both the old "I," which has been crucified ([link]Rom. 6:6[/link]), concerning which Paul said, "No longer I," and a new "I," concerning which Paul said, "I live." The old, terminated "I" was without divinity; the new "I" has God as life added to it. The new "I" came into being when the old "I" was resurrected and God was added to it. On the one hand, Paul had been terminated, but on the other hand, a resurrected Paul, one who was regenerated with God as his life, still lived. Furthermore, although Paul said, "No longer I," he also said, "It is Christ who lives in me," for it was Christ who lived, but it was in Paul that He lived. The two, Christ and Paul, had one life and one living.

We have died in Christ through His death, but now He lives in us through His resurrection. His living in us is entirely by His being the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45b[/link]). This point is fully developed in all the following chapters, where the Spirit is presented and emphasized as the very One whom we have received as life and in whom we should live.[br][br]The "I," the natural person, inclines to keep the law that it might be perfect ([link]Phil. 3:6[/link]), but God wants us to live Christ that God might be expressed in us through Him ([link]Phil. 1:20-21[/link]). Hence, God's economy is that the "I" be crucified in Christ's death and that Christ live in us in His resurrection. To keep the law is to exalt it above all things in our life; to live Christ is to make Him the center and everything in our life. The law was used by God for a period of time to keep His chosen people in custody for Christ ([link]3:23[/link]) and eventually to conduct them to Christ ([link]3:24[/link]) that they might receive Him as life and live Him to be God's expression. Because Christ has come, the function of the law has been terminated, and Christ must replace the law in our lives for the fulfillment of God's eternal purpose.
Not the physical life nor the soulish life but the spiritual and divine life.

In contrast to the way we live the physical and soulish life, we live the divine life not by sight nor by feeling. The divine life, the spiritual life in our spirit, is lived by the exercise of faith, which is stimulated by the presence of the life-giving Spirit.
Cf. note [link]16[sup]1[/sup][/link].

The title [i]Christ[/i] denotes mainly Christ's mission, which is to carry out God's plan; [i]the Son of God[/i] denotes Christ's person, which is for the imparting of God's life into us. Hence, the faith in which we live God's life is of the Son of God, the life-imparting One.
The Son of God loved us and purposely gave Himself up for us that He might impart the divine life into us.

verse.text: I do not nullify the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace of God; for if [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]righteousness is through law, then [xref]c[/xref]Christ has died [note]3[/note]for nothing.
verse.note: The grace of God is that Christ, the embodiment of the Triune God, has imparted the divine life into us through the life-giving Spirit. Not to live by this Spirit is to nullify the grace of God.

Christ died for us that in Him we may have righteousness, through which we may receive the divine life ([link]Rom. 5:18[/link], [link]21[/link]). This righteousness is not through law but through the death of Christ.
Or, without cause. If righteousness is through law, Christ has died without cause. However, righteousness is through Christ's death, and Christ's death has separated us from law.

verse.text: O foolish [xref]a[/xref]Galatians, [xref]b[/xref]who has bewitched you, before whose eyes Jesus Christ was openly portrayed [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]crucified?
verse.note: The cross is the center of God's operation in His economy. In this Epistle Paul was bringing the believers who had been distracted to the law back to the cross and encouraging them to behold Christ crucified, that they would never again be distracted to the law. This Epistle provides a thorough view of Christ crucified ([link]1:4[/link]; [link]2:19-21[/link]; [link]3:13[/link]; [link]5:24[/link]; [link]6:14[/link]).[br][br]The crucifixion of Christ indicates that all the requirements of the law have been fulfilled by the death of Christ, and that Christ through His death has released His life that it may be imparted into us in His resurrection to free us from bondage under the law. This was fully portrayed before the eyes of the Galatians in the word of the gospel. How could they neglect this and be bewitched, drifting back to the law? How foolish!

verse.text: This only I wish to learn from you, Did you [note]1[/note]receive the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Spirit out of the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]works of law or out of the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]hearing of [xref]d[/xref]faith?
verse.note: When the believers believe into Christ, they receive the Spirit. It is a serious misunderstanding to consider Christ as separate from the Spirit. At the time of regeneration we believed into Christ, and we also received the Spirit and were sealed with the Spirit ([link]Eph. 1:13[/link]). At that very moment an organic union took place — we were grafted into the Triune God ([link]Rom. 11:17[/link]), and the Spirit as the pledge ([link]Eph. 1:14[/link]) became the ultimate blessing of the gospel to us ([link]v. 14[/link]). After this, receiving the Spirit is a lifelong, continuous matter. God is supplying the Spirit to us continuously ([link]v. 5[/link]).

The Galatians, through the hearing of the gospel, believed in the crucified Christ, but they received the Spirit. The One who was crucified on the cross was Christ, but the One who entered into the believers was the Spirit. In His being crucified for the believers' redemption He was Christ, but in His indwelling the believers to be their life He is the Spirit. This is the all-inclusive life-giving Spirit, who is the all-inclusive and ultimate blessing of the gospel. The believers receive such a divine Spirit by the hearing of faith, not by the works of law. He enters into the believers and lives in them not by their keeping of the law but by their faith in the crucified and resurrected Christ.[br][br]In the first two chapters of this Epistle there is Christ in the divine revelation as the focal point of God's economy, but in the last four chapters there is the Spirit in our experience for us to have the divine life ([link]ch. 3[/link]), to be born of God ([link]ch. 4[/link]), to live and walk by the regenerated life ([link]ch. 5[/link]), and to take the divine purpose as our goal ([link]ch. 6[/link]). Thus, we enjoy Christ continually as the all-inclusive life-giving Spirit ([link]v. 5a[/link]).

The law was the basic condition for the relationship between man and God in God's Old Testament economy ([link]v. 23[/link]); faith is the unique way for God to carry out His New Testament economy with man ([link]1 Tim. 1:4[/link]). The law is related to the flesh ([link]Rom. 7:5[/link]) and depends on the effort of the flesh, the very flesh that is the expression of the "I." Faith is related to the Spirit and trusts in the operation of the Spirit, the very Spirit who is the realization of Christ. In the Old Testament the "I" and the flesh played an important role in the keeping of the law. In the New Testament Christ and the Spirit take over the position of the "I" and the flesh, and faith replaces the law, that we may live Christ by the Spirit. To keep the law by the flesh is man's natural way; it is in the darkness of man's concept and results in death and wretchedness ([link]Rom. 7:10-11[/link], [link]24[/link]). To receive the Spirit out of the hearing of faith is God's revealed way; it is in the light of God's revelation and issues in life and glory ([link]Rom. 8:2[/link], [link]6[/link], [link]10-11[/link], [link]30[/link]). Hence, we must treasure the hearing of faith, not the works of law. It is by the hearing of faith that we received the Spirit so that we might participate in God's promised blessing and live Christ. The faith mentioned in [link]vv. 7[/link], [link]8[/link], [link]9[/link], [link]11[/link], [link]12[/link], [link]23[/link], [link]24[/link], and [link]25[/link] of this chapter is this faith. (See note [link]23[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].)

verse.text: Are you so foolish? Having [note]1[/note]begun by the [note]2[/note]Spirit, are you now being [note]1[/note]perfected by the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]flesh?
verse.note: To begin by the Spirit is to begin by faith in Christ; to be perfected by the flesh is to be perfected by works of law ([link]v. 2[/link]).

The Spirit, who is the resurrected Christ, is of life; the flesh, which is our fallen man, is of sin and death. We should not begin by the Spirit and attempt to be perfected by the flesh. Since we have begun by the Spirit, we should be perfected by the Spirit and have nothing to do with the flesh. In [link]2:20[/link] the contrast is between Christ and the "I"; here the contrast is between the Spirit and the flesh. This indicates that the Spirit is Christ and the flesh is the "I" in our experience. From [link]ch. 3[/link] to the end of the Epistle, the Spirit is Christ in our life experience. In revelation, it is Christ; in experience, it is the Spirit.[br][br]The flesh is condemned and repudiated throughout this book ([link]1:16[/link]; [link]2:16[/link]; [link]3:3[/link]; [link]4:23[/link], [link]29[/link]; [link]5:13[/link], [link]16-17[/link], [link]19[/link], [link]24[/link]; [link]6:8[/link], [link]12-13[/link]), and from [link]ch. 3[/link] every chapter gives a contrast between the flesh and the Spirit ([link]v. 3[/link]; [link]4:29[/link]; [link]5:16-17[/link], [link]19[/link], [link]22[/link]; [link]6:8[/link]). The flesh is the uttermost expression of the fallen tripartite man, and the Spirit is the ultimate realization of the processed Triune God. The flesh inclines to keep the law and is tested by the law; the Spirit is received and enjoyed out of faith. God's economy delivers us from the flesh to the Spirit that we may participate in the blessing of the riches of the Triune God. This cannot take place by the flesh keeping the law but by the Spirit being received out of faith and experienced through faith.

verse.text: Have you [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]suffered so many things [xref]b[/xref]in vain, if indeed it was in vain?
verse.note: The Galatians suffered persecution because of their faith in Christ, which had turned them to Christ from the Jewish religion and heathen customs.

verse.text: He therefore who [note]1[/note]bountifully [xref]a[/xref]supplies to you the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Spirit and [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]does works of power among you, [i]does He do it[/i] out of the [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]works of law or out of the hearing of faith?
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]supplies fully, bountifully, and liberally.[/i] See [link]Phil. 1:19[/link]. On God's side, He supplies the Spirit bountifully; on our side, we receive the Spirit. Day by day a marvelous divine transmission takes place: God supplies and we receive. The way to open ourselves to this heavenly transmission to receive the supply of the all-inclusive life-giving Spirit is to exercise our spirit to pray and call on the Lord.

The all-inclusive compound Spirit, typified by the compound ointment in [link]Exo. 30:23-25[/link]. This is the Spirit mentioned in [link]John 7:39[/link], who is the life-imparting Christ in resurrection. To the believers in God's New Testament economy, this Spirit is the bountiful supply. The supplying of this Spirit is altogether not out of the works of law but out of faith in the crucified and glorified Christ.
Lit., operates.

In an attempt to frustrate God's economy, Satan, the enemy of God, uses the law — which was given by God to serve His purpose temporarily — to keep God's chosen people from His economy and to distract them from it. The law is misused when it is used to stir up man's fallen desire to exalt himself by keeping the law that he might have a self-made righteousness.

verse.text: Even as [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]"Abraham [xref]b[/xref]believed God, and it was accounted to him for righteousness."
verse.note: In drifting back to the law, the bewitched Galatians clung to Moses, through whom the law was given; but Paul referred them to Abraham, who was the father of faith. Faith was of God's original economy; the law was added later because of the transgressions ([link]v. 19[/link]). After Christ fulfilled the law through His death, God wanted His people to return to His original economy. With Abraham it was not a matter of keeping the law but of believing God. It should be so with all the New Testament believers.

verse.text: Know then that they who are of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]faith, these are [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]sons of Abraham.
verse.note: I.e., the faith.

Works of law make people disciples of Moses ([link]John 9:28[/link]), a relationship that has nothing whatever to do with life. Faith in Christ makes the New Testament believers sons of God, a relationship altogether of life. We, the New Testament believers, were born sons of the fallen Adam, and in Adam, because of transgressions, we were under the law of Moses. But we have been reborn sons of Abraham and have been freed from the law of Moses by faith in Christ.

verse.text: And the Scripture, foreseeing that God would [xref]a[/xref]justify the Gentiles out of faith, announced the [note]1[/note]gospel beforehand to Abraham: [xref]b[/xref]"In you shall all the nations be [xref]c[/xref]blessed."
verse.note: The promise God gave to Abraham, "In you shall all the nations be blessed," was the gospel. It was preached to Abraham not only before the accomplishing of redemption by Christ but also before the giving of the law through Moses. What God promised to Abraham corresponds with what God accomplished through Christ, which is the fulfillment of His promise to Abraham. The New Testament economy is a continuation of God's dealing with Abraham, having nothing to do with the law of Moses. All the New Testament believers should be in this continuation and should have nothing to do with the law given through Moses.

verse.text: So then they who are of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]faith are [note]2[/note]blessed with [note]3[/note]believing Abraham.
verse.note: I.e., the faith.
Faith in Christ brings us into the blessing that God promised to Abraham, which is the promise of the Spirit ([link]v. 14[/link]).
Under God's dealing, Abraham was not working to please God but was believing Him.

verse.text: For as many as are of the [xref]a[/xref]works of law are under a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]curse; for it is written, [xref]c[/xref]"Cursed is everyone who does not continue in all the things written in the book of the law to do them."
verse.note: Faith in Christ had brought the Galatian believers into the blessing in Christ, causing them to enjoy the grace of life in the Spirit; but the Judaizers bewitched them and caused them to come under the curse of the law, thus depriving them of the enjoyment of Christ and causing them to fall from grace ([link]5:4[/link]).

verse.text: And that [note]1[/note]by law [xref]a[/xref]no one is justified before God is evident because, [xref]b[/xref]"The righteous one shall have life and [xref]c[/xref]live [note]2[/note]by faith";
verse.note: Lit., in; meaning "in the power of, in virtue of" (Darby's New Translation).
Lit., out of faith; in contrast to [i]by law.[/i]

verse.text: But the law is not of faith, yet, [xref]a[/xref]"He who does them shall live [note]1[/note]because of them."
verse.note: Lit., in; meaning [i]in virtue of.[/i]

verse.text: Christ has [xref]a[/xref]redeemed us out of the [xref]b[/xref]curse of the law, having [note]1[/note]become a curse on our behalf; because it is written, [xref]c[/xref]"Cursed is everyone hanging on a [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]tree";
verse.note: As our Substitute on the cross, Christ not only bore the curse for us but also became a curse for us. The curse of the law issued from the sin of man ([link]Gen. 3:17[/link]). When Christ took away our sin on the cross, He redeemed us out of the curse of the law.
I.e., the cross.

verse.text: In order that the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blessing of Abraham might come to the Gentiles [xref]b[/xref]in Christ Jesus, that we might [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]receive the [xref]d[/xref]promise of the [note]3[/note][xref]e[/xref]Spirit through [xref]f[/xref]faith.
verse.note: The blessing promised by God to Abraham ([link]Gen. 12:3[/link]) for all the nations of the earth. The promise was fulfilled, and the blessing has come to the nations in Christ through His redemption by the cross.

In the gospel we have received not only the blessing of forgiveness, washing, and cleansing; even more, we have received the greatest blessing, which is the Triune God — the Father, Son, and Spirit — as the processed, all-inclusive life-giving Spirit dwelling in us in a most subjective way for our enjoyment. Oh, what a blessing that we can enjoy such an all-inclusive One as our daily portion!

This verse indicates that the Spirit is the blessing that God promised to Abraham for all the nations and that has been received by the believers through faith in Christ. The Spirit is the compound Spirit, as mentioned in note [link]5[sup]2[/sup][/link], and actually is God Himself processed in His Trinity through incarnation, crucifixion, resurrection, ascension, and descension that we may receive Him as our life and our everything. This is the focus of the gospel of God.[br][br]The physical aspect of the blessing that God promised to Abraham was the good land ([link]Gen. 12:7[/link]; [link]13:15[/link]; [link]17:8[/link]; [link]26:3-4[/link]), which was a type of the all-inclusive Christ (see [link]Col. 1:12[/link] and note 2). Since Christ is eventually realized as the all-inclusive life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:17[/link]), the blessing of the promised Spirit corresponds with the blessing of the land promised to Abraham. Actually, the Spirit as the realization of Christ in our experience is the good land as the source of God's bountiful supply for us to enjoy.

verse.text: Brothers, I speak [xref]a[/xref]according to man, though [i]it is[/i] a man's covenant, yet when it has been ratified, no one nullifies [i]it[/i] or makes additions [i]to it.[/i]

But [xref]a[/xref]to Abraham were the [xref]b[/xref]promises spoken and [xref]c[/xref]to his seed. He does not say, And to the seeds, as concerning many, but as concerning one: "And to your [xref]d[/xref]seed," who is [note]1[/note][xref]e[/xref]Christ.
verse.note: Christ is the seed, and the seed is the heir who inherits the promises. Here, Christ is the unique seed who inherits the promises. Hence, in order to inherit the promised blessing, we must be one with Christ. Outside of Him we cannot inherit the promises given by God to Abraham. In God's eyes Abraham has only one seed, that is, Christ. We must be in Him that we may participate in the promises given to Abraham. He is not only the seed who inherits the promises but also the blessing of the promises to be inherited by us. For the Galatian believers to turn back from Christ to the law meant that they would forfeit both the Heir and the inheritance of the promises.

verse.text: And I say this: A [note]1[/note]covenant previously ratified by God, the [note]2[/note]law, having come [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]four hundred and thirty years after, does not annul so as to make the [xref]b[/xref]promise of none effect.
verse.note: This indicates that the promise God gave to Abraham became a covenant, which is more firm than a promise. The word, the promise, and the covenant are the gospel that was preached to Abraham. The gospel is the covenant, the covenant is the promise, and the promise is the word spoken by God. Although the gospel is a matter of the new testament, it is important to realize that the new testament is a continuation, or repetition, of God's promise to Abraham.

God's promise to Abraham was given first. The law came 430 years later. The promise was permanent, but the law was temporary. The law, which came later and was temporary, cannot annul the promise, which was given first and was permanent. The Galatians left the first and permanent promise and went back to the later and temporary law.

Counted from the time God gave Abraham the promise in [link]Gen. 12[/link] to the time He gave the law through Moses in [link]Exo. 20[/link]. This period was considered by God as the time of the children of Israel's dwelling in Egypt ([link]Exo. 12:40-41[/link]). The four hundred years mentioned in [link]Gen. 15:13[/link] and [link]Acts 7:6[/link] is counted from the time Ishmael mocked Isaac in [link]Gen. 21[/link] to the time the children of Israel came out of the Egyptian tyranny in [link]Exo. 12[/link]. This is the period during which Abraham's descendants suffered persecution from the Gentiles.

verse.text: For if the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]inheritance is of law, it is no longer of promise; but to Abraham God has graciously given [i]it[/i] through [xref]b[/xref]promise.
verse.note: The law does not give; it only requires. Inheritance is not of law but of promise. Hence, the inheritance was graciously given to Abraham through promise.

verse.text: Why then the [xref]a[/xref]law? It was [note]1[/note]added because of the [xref]b[/xref]transgressions until the [xref]c[/xref]seed should come to whom the promise was made, it being [note]2[/note]ordained through [xref]d[/xref]angels in the hand of a [note]3[/note][xref]e[/xref]mediator.
verse.note: The law was not there in the origination of God's economy. It was added because of man's transgressions, while God's economy was proceeding, and was to be in effect until the seed, Christ, should come, to whom God's promise was made. Since it was added because of man's transgressions, it should have been deducted when those transgressions were taken away. And since Christ, the seed, has come, the law must be terminated.
Because the law was ordained through angels in the hand of a mediator and, unlike the promise, was not given by God directly to the people, it is not primary but secondary in God's economy.
The man Moses.

verse.text: But a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]mediator is not [i]a mediator[/i] for one, but God is [xref]b[/xref]one.
verse.note: With the law there is a mediator between two parties, God and the children of Israel. With the promise there is only God, who is directly related to the one who receives the promise, without a go-between. The responsibility with respect to the law depends not on one party but on two, whereas the responsibility with regard to the promise depends only on the giver, God. Hence, the law is inferior to the promise. The Galatians gave up the superior and went back to the inferior.

verse.text: Is then the law against the promises of God? [xref]a[/xref]Absolutely not! For if a law had been given which was able to [note]1[/note]give life, [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]righteousness would have indeed been of law.
verse.note: The law was able only to demand and condemn; it could not give life. (See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in Rom. 7[/link].) There is no life in the law; there are only commandments. Life is in Christ ([link]John 1:4[/link]). He is the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]), the only One who is able to give life. The giving of life is the focal point of the apostle's revelation. We should take only the One who gives life.

There must be righteousness in order for life to be given. Righteousness, however, is not of law but in Christ ([link]Rom. 5:17-18[/link]). Hence, the law is not able to give life. Furthermore, since the law cannot give life, it has no power to fulfill its requirements so that righteousness may be produced. Hence, in this sense also, righteousness is not of law.

verse.text: But the Scripture has [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]shut up [note]2[/note]all under [xref]b[/xref]sin in order that the [xref]c[/xref]promise out of [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]faith in Jesus Christ might be given to those who [xref]e[/xref]believe.
verse.note: As a jailer shuts up prisoners. The Scripture, personified here, has shut up all mankind under sin, not that the law might be kept by the imprisoned sinners but that God's promise might be given to the believers by faith in Christ. To be shut up under sin is to be shut up under law, as revealed in [link]v. 23[/link].
Lit., all things; i.e., all mankind.
Or, faith of Jesus Christ. See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in Rom. 3[/link].

verse.text: But before [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]faith came we were [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]guarded [xref]c[/xref]under law, being [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]shut up [note]4[/note]unto the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]faith which was to be revealed.
verse.note: See notes [link]23[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link] and [link]2[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 3[/link]. So also in [link]v. 25[/link]. Faith was not revealed until Christ came (cf. [link]John 1:12[/link]; [link]3:16[/link], [link]18[/link]).
Kept in custody, kept in ward.

To be guarded under law by being shut up under law is to be like sheep enclosed in a fold ([link]John 10:1[/link], [link]16[/link]). In God's economy the law was used as a fold to keep God's chosen people until Christ came (see note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in John 10[/link]). Since Christ has come, God's people should no longer be kept under the law (see note [link]9[sup]2[/sup] in John 10[/link]).
Or, with a view to. Indicating that shutting up has an object; i.e., it consummates in the faith, it brings the guarded people to the faith.

verse.text: So then the [xref]a[/xref]law has become our [note]1[/note]child-conductor unto [xref]b[/xref]Christ that we might be justified out of [xref]c[/xref]faith.
verse.note: Or, escort, guardian, custodian; one who cares for a child who is under age and conducts him to the schoolmaster. The law was used by God as a custodian, a guardian, a child-conductor, to watch over His chosen people before Christ came, and to escort and bring them to Christ when He did come, that they might be justified by faith and participate in the blessing promised and covenanted by God.

verse.text: But since [xref]a[/xref]faith has come, we are [note]1[/note]no longer [xref]b[/xref]under a child-conductor.
verse.note: Since faith in Christ has come, we do not need to be under the guarding law any longer.

verse.text: For you are all [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sons of God through [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]faith [xref]c[/xref]in Christ Jesus.
verse.note: Sons of full age, who have outgrown the custody of the slave guardian. Under the old testament, God's chosen people were considered infants. Now, under the new testament, they are considered sons of full age, who will inherit the promised blessing — the all-inclusive Spirit of Christ.
Faith in Christ brings us into Christ, making us one with Christ, in whom is the sonship. We must be identified with Christ through faith so that in Him we may be sons of God.

verse.text: For as many of you as were [xref]a[/xref]baptized [note]1[/note]into Christ have [xref]b[/xref]put on Christ.
verse.note: To believe is to believe into Christ ([link]John 3:16[/link]), and to be baptized is to be baptized into Christ. By both faith and baptism we have entered into Christ, having thus put on Christ and become identified with Christ. Baptism practiced in a proper, genuine, and living way puts the believers into the name of the Triune God, the divine name ([link]Matt. 28:19[/link]); into Christ, a living person ([link]Gal. 3:27[/link]); into the death of Christ, an effective death ([link]Rom. 6:3[/link]); and into the Body of Christ, a living organism ([link]1 Cor. 12:13[/link]), that the believers may enter into an organic union not only with Christ but also with His Body. Furthermore, baptism brings the believers out of their old state into a new one, terminating their old life and germinating them with the new life of Christ that they may live in the Body of Christ, an organism, by the elements of the Triune God.

verse.text: There [note]1[/note]cannot be [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Jew nor Greek, there cannot be [note]3[/note]slave nor free man, there cannot be [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]male and female; for you are all [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]one [xref]d[/xref]in Christ Jesus.
verse.note: See note [link]11[sup]2[/sup] in Col. 3[/link].
Differences among races and nationalities.
Differences in social rank.
Differences between the sexes.

The believers are one in Christ by His resurrection life and His divine nature to be the one new man, as mentioned in [link]Eph. 2:15[/link]. This one new man is absolutely in Christ. There is no room for our natural being, our natural disposition, and our natural character; in this one new man Christ is all and in all ([link]Col. 3:10-11[/link]). This oneness in Christ is achieved through baptism, which terminates all the divisive distinctions and ushers the believers into the divine organic union with the processed Triune God, resulting in the believers' subjective assurance that they are one with one another.

verse.text: And if you are of [xref]a[/xref]Christ, then you are [note]1[/note]Abraham's [xref]b[/xref]seed, [xref]c[/xref]heirs according to [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]promise.
verse.note: Abraham has only one seed, Christ ([link]v. 16[/link]). Hence, to be Abraham's seed we must be of Christ, be a part of Christ. Because we are one with Christ, we too are Abraham's seed, heirs according to promise, inheriting God's promised blessing, which is the all-inclusive Spirit as the ultimate consummation of the processed God, who is our portion. Under the new testament, the believers as God's chosen people, being sons of full age, are such heirs, not under law but in Christ. Like Ishmael ([link]4:23[/link]), the Judaizers, who remained under law and kept themselves apart from Christ, were Abraham's descendants according to the flesh; they were not like Isaac ([link]4:28[/link]), who was Abraham's heir according to promise. But the believers in Christ are such heirs, inheriting the promised blessing. Hence, we should remain in Christ and not turn to the law.[br][br]Since the law is unable to give us life ([link]v. 21[/link]), it cannot produce the sons of God; but the Spirit, who is received out of faith ([link]v. 2[/link]) and who gives us life ([link]2 Cor. 3:6[/link]), can. The law kept God's chosen people under its custody until faith came ([link]v. 23[/link]). Faith in Christ, who is the all-inclusive life-giving Spirit, makes God's chosen people Abraham's seed as "the stars of the heavens" ([link]Gen. 22:17[/link]) according to God's promise.

This chapter reveals that God gave the promise to Abraham according to His eternal purpose. Before this promise was fulfilled, the law was given to serve as the custodian of God's chosen people. Then, at the appointed time Christ, the promised seed, came to fulfill the promise and brought in the promised blessing. This is grace. Hence, grace came with Christ and with the fulfillment of the promise. All this is on God's side. On our side, we need a way to apprehend, realize, and enjoy all that Christ, the seed, is and has accomplished. Therefore, there is grace on God's side, and there is faith on our side. Now, since we have grace, faith, and the seed that has fulfilled the promise, we no longer need the law to serve as our custodian. Hence, we must set aside the law and turn from the custodian to stay with Christ that we may enjoy the promised blessing by remaining in grace and faith. This blessing is nothing less than the processed Triune God as the all-inclusive life-giving Spirit.

verse.text: But I say, As long as the [xref]a[/xref]heir is a [note]1[/note]child, he does not differ at all from a [xref]b[/xref]slave, though he is lord of all;
verse.note: The same Greek word as for [i]little children[/i] in [link]Eph. 4:14[/link], referring to a minor. So also in [link]v. 3[/link].

verse.text: But he is [xref]a[/xref]under [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]guardians and [xref]c[/xref]stewards until the [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]time appointed by the father.
verse.note: Guardians are wardens, and stewards are administrators. These describe the functions of the law in God's economy.
The time appointed by the father refers to the time of the New Testament, beginning with the first coming of Christ.

verse.text: So also we, when we were children, were kept in [xref]a[/xref]slavery under the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]elements of the world;
verse.note: The same Greek word as for [i]rudiments[/i] in [link]Heb. 5:12[/link]. I.e., elementary principles, referring to the rudimentary teachings of the law (see note [link]8[sup]3[/sup] in Col. 2[/link]). So also in [link]v. 9[/link].

verse.text: But when the [note]1[/note]fullness of the [xref]a[/xref]time came, God [xref]b[/xref]sent forth His [xref]c[/xref]Son, born of a [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]woman, born under [note]3[/note][xref]e[/xref]law,
verse.note: The completion of the Old Testament time, which occurred at the time appointed by the Father ([link]v. 2[/link]).
The virgin Mary ([link]Luke 1:27-35[/link]). The Son of God was born of her to be the seed of woman, as promised in [link]Gen. 3:15[/link].
Christ was born under law, as revealed in [link]Luke 2:21-24[/link], [link]27[/link], and kept the law, as revealed in the four Gospels.

verse.text: That He might [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]redeem those under law that we might receive the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]sonship.
verse.note: God's chosen people were shut up by the law under its custody ([link]3:23[/link]). Christ was born under law in order to redeem God's chosen people from the custody of the law that they might receive the sonship and become the sons of God. Hence, they should not return to the custody of the law to be under its slavery, as the Galatians were seduced to do, but should remain in the sonship of God to enjoy the life supply of the Spirit in Christ.

Christ's redemption brings us into the sonship of God that we may enjoy the divine life. God's economy is not to make us keepers of the law, obeying the commandments and ordinances of the law, which was given only for a temporary purpose. God's economy is to make us sons of God, who inherit the blessing of God's promise, which was given for His eternal purpose. God's eternal purpose is to have many sons for His corporate expression ([link]Heb. 2:10[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:29[/link]). Hence, He predestinated us unto sonship ([link]Eph. 1:5[/link]) and regenerated us to be His sons ([link]John 1:12-13[/link]). We should remain in His sonship that we may become His heirs to inherit all that He has planned for His eternal expression, and should not appreciate the law and thereby be distracted to Judaism.

verse.text: And because you are [xref]a[/xref]sons, God has [xref]b[/xref]sent forth the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]Spirit of His Son into our [note]2[/note]hearts, [note]3[/note]crying, [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]Abba, Father!
verse.note: God's Son is the embodiment of the divine life ([link]1 John 5:12[/link]). Hence, the Spirit of God's Son is the Spirit of life ([link]Rom. 8:2[/link]). God gives us His Spirit of life not because we are law keepers but because we are His sons. As law keepers, we have no right to enjoy God's Spirit of life; as the sons of God, we have the position with the full right to participate in the Spirit of God, who has the bountiful supply of life. Such a Spirit, the Spirit of the Son of God, is the focus of the blessing of God's promise to Abraham ([link]3:14[/link]).[br][br][link]Verses 4-6[/link] of this chapter speak of the Triune God's producing of many sons for the fulfillment of His eternal purpose. God the Father sent forth God the Son to redeem us from the law that we might receive the sonship. He also sent forth God the Spirit to impart His life into us that we might become His sons in reality.

Actually, the Spirit of God came into our spirit at the time of our regeneration ([link]John 3:6[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:16[/link]). Because our spirit is hidden in our heart ([link]1 Pet. 3:4[/link]), and because the word here refers to a matter that is related to our feeling and understanding, both of which belong to our heart, this verse says that the Spirit of God's Son was sent into our hearts.

The parallel verse, [link]Rom. 8:15[/link], says that we who have received a spirit of sonship cry in this spirit, "Abba, Father!" whereas here it says that the Spirit of God's Son is crying in our hearts, "Abba, Father!" This indicates that our regenerated spirit and the Spirit of God are mingled as one, and that our spirit is in our heart. This indicates also that the sonship of God is realized by us through our subjective experience in the depth of our being. In this verse, Paul appealed to such an experience of the Galatian believers for the supporting of his revelation. This appeal was quite convincing and subduing because it contained not only objective doctrines but also subjective, experiential facts.

[i]Abba[/i] is an Aramaic word, and [i]Father[/i] is the translation of the Greek word [i]Pater.[/i] Such a term was used first by the Lord Jesus in Gethsemane while He was praying to the Father ([link]Mark 14:36[/link]). The combining of the Aramaic title with the Greek title expresses a stronger affection in crying to the Father. Such an affectionate cry implies an intimate relationship in life between a genuine son and a begetting father.

verse.text: So then you are [note]1[/note]no longer a [xref]a[/xref]slave but a son; and if a [note]2[/note]son, an [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]heir also [note]4[/note]through God.
verse.note: The New Testament believer is no longer a slave to works under law but is a son in life under grace.
See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].
One who is of full age according to the law (the Roman law is used for illustration) and who is qualified to inherit the father's estate.

The New Testament believers become heirs of God not through the law nor through their fleshly father but through God, even the Triune God — the Father, who sent forth the Son and the Spirit ([link]vv. 4[/link], [link]6[/link]); the Son, who accomplished redemption for sonship ([link]v. 5[/link]); and the Spirit, who carries out the sonship within us ([link]v. 6[/link]).

verse.text: However at that time, [xref]a[/xref]not knowing God, you were [xref]b[/xref]slaves to the [xref]c[/xref]gods which by [note]1[/note]nature are not [i]gods;[/i]
verse.note: The gods, the idols, do not have the divine nature. They were considered gods by their superstitious worshippers, but by nature they are not gods.

verse.text: But now, having come to [xref]a[/xref]know God, or rather having been [xref]b[/xref]known by God, how is it that you turn again to the [xref]c[/xref]weak and poor [xref]d[/xref]elements, to which you desire to [note]1[/note]be [xref]e[/xref]enslaved yet again?
verse.note: Lit., serve as a slave.

verse.text: You observe [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]days and [note]2[/note]months and [note]3[/note]seasons and [note]4[/note]years;
verse.note: Sabbaths, new moons ([link]Isa. 66:23[/link]).

Sacred months, such as the first, Abib, the ear month ([link]Exo. 13:4[/link]); the second, Ziv, the flower month ([link]1 Kings 6:1[/link], [link]37[/link]); the seventh, Ethanim, the month of streaming rivers ([link]1 Kings 8:2[/link]); and the eighth, Bul, the month of rain ([link]1 Kings 6:38[/link]).
Festal seasons, such as the Passover, Pentecost, and the Feast of Tabernacles ([link]2 Chron. 8:13[/link]).
Perhaps sabbatical years ([link]Lev. 25:4[/link]).

verse.text: I fear for you, [xref]a[/xref]lest I have labored upon you in [note]1[/note]vain.
verse.note: Paul labored upon the Galatians to bring them into Christ under grace. Their turning to the Jewish religious observances could have caused Paul's labor upon them to be in vain.

verse.text: Become [note]1[/note]as I am, because I also am [note]2[/note]as you are, brothers, I beseech you; you have [note]3[/note]not wronged me at all.
verse.note: Paul was free from the bondage of Jewish observances. He besought the Galatians to become as he was.
Paul became as a Gentile was, for the truth of the gospel.
The Galatians had not wronged Paul in the past. Paul expected that they would not wrong him now.

verse.text: And you know that [note]1[/note]because of weakness of my flesh I [xref]a[/xref]announced the gospel to you the first time.
verse.note: In his first ministry journey Paul was detained in Galatia because of physical weakness. While there, he preached the gospel to the Galatians.

verse.text: And that which was a trial to you in my flesh you did not despise nor [note]1[/note]loathe, but you [xref]a[/xref]received me as an [xref]b[/xref]angel of God, [i]indeed[/i] as Christ Jesus.
verse.note: Lit., spit out.

verse.text: Where then is [note]1[/note]your felicitation? For I testify concerning you that if possible you would have plucked out your [note]2[/note]eyes and given [i]them[/i] to me.
verse.note: The Galatians formerly considered it a blessing that Paul was detained in their place and preached the gospel to them. They were happy about this and boasted of it. That became their felicitation. However, now that they had departed from Paul's preaching of the gospel, the apostle questioned them, "Where then is your felicitation, your happiness, your blessedness?"

The Galatians appreciated Paul's preaching and loved him to such an extent that they would have plucked out their eyes and given them to him. This may indicate that Paul's physical weakness ([link]v. 13[/link]) was in his eyes. This can perhaps be confirmed by his use of large letters in his writing to them ([link]6:11[/link]). This weakness may also have been the thorn in his flesh, a physical weakness, which he prayed would be removed from him ([link]2 Cor. 12:7-9[/link]).

verse.text: So then have I become your enemy by presenting the [xref]a[/xref]truth to you?
They are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]zealous of you, [i]but[/i] [note]2[/note]not rightly; but they desire to [note]3[/note]shut you out that you may be [note]4[/note]zealous of them.
verse.note: I.e., zealously court you.
Not in an honorable, commendable way.
I.e., exclude you from the proper preaching of the gospel, the gospel of grace.
I.e., zealously court them.

verse.text: But [i]it is[/i] always good to be zealous in a good thing, and [note]1[/note]not only [xref]a[/xref]when I am present with you.
verse.note: It is always good to zealously court someone in a good thing or in the proper preaching of the gospel. However, this should have taken place not only when Paul was present with them. By this word Paul indicated that he was not narrow, i.e., he did not prohibit others from preaching the gospel to the Galatians; rather, he rejoiced in others' preaching ([link]Phil. 1:18[/link]).

verse.text: My [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]children, with whom I [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]travail again in birth until [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]Christ is [note]4[/note]formed [xref]d[/xref]in you,
verse.note: Paul considered himself the begetting father and the Galatian believers his children begotten of him in Christ (cf. [link]1 Cor. 4:15[/link]; [link]Philem. 10[/link]).

Painful toil in childbirth. In this metaphor Paul likened himself to a mother who gives birth to a child. He had labored in this way to regenerate the Galatians when he first preached the gospel to them. Because they deviated from the gospel that he had preached to them, he was toiling again in travail until Christ would be formed in them.

Christ, a living person, is the focus of Paul's gospel. Paul's preaching, which differed greatly from the teaching of the law in letters, was to bring forth Christ, the Son of the living God, in the believers. Hence, this book is emphatically Christ-centered. Christ was crucified ([link]3:1[/link]) to redeem us out of the curse of the law ([link]3:13[/link]) and rescue us out of the evil religious course of the world ([link]1:4[/link]), and He was resurrected from the dead ([link]1:1[/link]) that He might live in us ([link]2:20[/link]). We were baptized into Him, being identified with Him, and have put Him on, clothing ourselves with Him ([link]3:27[/link]). Thus, we are in Him ([link]3:28[/link]) and have become of Him ([link]3:29[/link]; [link]5:24[/link]). On the other hand, He has been revealed in us ([link]1:16[/link]), He is now living in us ([link]2:20[/link]), and He will be formed in us ([link]v. 19[/link]). To Him the law has conducted us ([link]3:24[/link]), and in Him we are all sons of God ([link]3:26[/link]). It is in Him that we inherit God's promised blessing and enjoy the all-inclusive Spirit ([link]3:14[/link]). Furthermore, it is in Him that we are all one ([link]3:28[/link]). We should not be deprived of all profit from Him and thus be severed from Him ([link]5:4[/link]). We need Him to supply us with His grace in our spirit ([link]6:18[/link]) that we may live Him.

When the Galatian believers were regenerated through Paul's preaching of the gospel to them the first time, Christ was born into them but not formed in them. Here the apostle was travailing again that Christ might be formed in them. To have Christ formed in us is to have Christ fully grown in us. First, Christ was born into us at the time we repented and believed in Him, then He lives in us in our Christian life ([link]2:20[/link]), and, finally, He will be formed in us at our maturity. Christ's being formed in us is needed that we may be sons of full age and heirs to inherit God's promised blessing, and that we may mature in the divine sonship.

verse.text: Indeed, I wish I could be present with you now and [note]1[/note]change my [note]2[/note]tone because I am [note]3[/note]perplexed about you.
verse.note: The apostle wished to change his tone from one of severity to one of affection, like the tone of a mother speaking lovingly to her children.
Lit., voice.
Paul was puzzled in dealing with the Galatians. He was searching for the best way to recover them from their deviation from Christ.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Tell me, you who desire to be [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]under the law, do you not hear the [note]3[/note]law?
verse.note: In [link]vv. 21-31[/link] there are two women, Hagar and Sarah; two Jerusalems, one earthly and the other heavenly; two covenants, one of the law and the other of promise; and two sons, one according to the flesh and the other according to the Spirit. The apostle wanted the Galatians to know that they were children of the Jerusalem above, children of the free woman, and he wanted them to appropriate the covenant of promise and, according to the Spirit, enjoy the all-inclusive Spirit as the blessing of the gospel ([link]3:14[/link]). In this section Sarah, the free woman, symbolizes the covenant of promise, which is symbolized also by the Jerusalem above, who is our mother; the mother symbolizes grace, by which we are born to be the children of God, who is the very source of grace. Hence, the free woman, the covenant of promise, the Jerusalem above, and the mother all refer to God's grace, which is the very means of our spiritual birth. It was from this grace — Christ — that the Galatians who had been distracted by Judaism fell away ([link]5:4[/link]).
This book deals strongly with the matter of deviating from Christ by being under the law. Such deviation shuts the believers out from the enjoyment of Christ as their life and their everything.

According to the succeeding verses, the law here includes the book of Genesis. The entire Old Testament is called the Law and the Prophets ([link]Matt. 22:40[/link]). The first part is the Law, and the second, the Prophets.

verse.text: For it is written that Abraham had two sons, [xref]a[/xref]one of the [xref]b[/xref]maidservant and [xref]c[/xref]one of the [xref]d[/xref]free woman.
However the one of the maidservant was born [note]1[/note]according to the [xref]a[/xref]flesh, but the one of the free woman [i]was born[/i] [note]1[/note]through [xref]b[/xref]promise.
verse.note: [i]According to the flesh[/i] means by man's fleshly effort; [i]through promise[/i] means through God's power in grace, which is implied in God's promise. Ishmael was born in the former way, but Isaac in the latter.

verse.text: These things are spoken allegorically, for [note]1[/note]these women are [note]2[/note]two [xref]a[/xref]covenants, one from [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]Mount Sinai, bringing forth [i]children[/i] unto [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]slavery, which is [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]Hagar.
verse.note: Referring to the two women in [link]v. 22[/link].

One is the covenant of promise given to Abraham, which is related to the new testament, the covenant of grace, and the other is the covenant of law given to Moses, which has nothing to do with the new testament. Sarah, the free woman, symbolizes the covenant of promise, and Hagar, the maidservant, the covenant of law.
Where the law was given ([link]Exo. 19:20[/link]; [link]24:12[/link]).
Slavery under law.

Hagar, the concubine of Abraham, signifies the law. Hence, the position of the law is like that of a concubine. Sarah, the wife of Abraham, symbolizes the grace of God ([link]John 1:17[/link]), which has the rightful position in God's economy. Like Hagar, the law brought forth children unto slavery, such as the Judaizers. Like Sarah, grace brings forth children unto sonship; these are the New Testament believers. They are no longer under law but under grace ([link]Rom. 6:14[/link]). They should stand in grace ([link]Rom. 5:2[/link]) and not fall from it ([link]5:4[/link]).

verse.text: Now this Hagar is Sinai the mountain in [xref]a[/xref]Arabia and corresponds to the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem which now is, for she [note]2[/note]is in [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]slavery with her children.
verse.note: Jerusalem, as God's choice ([link]1 Kings 14:21[/link]; [link]Psa. 48:2[/link], [link]8[/link]), should belong to the covenant of promise, symbolized by Sarah. However, because it brings God's chosen people into the bondage of the law, it corresponds with Mount Sinai, which belongs to the covenant of the law, symbolized by Hagar.
Lit., serves as a slave.
A slave under law. At the apostle's time Jerusalem and her children were slaves under law.

verse.text: But the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem above is free, which is our mother;
verse.note: The Jerusalem above eventually will be the New Jerusalem in the new heaven and new earth ([link]Rev. 21:1-2[/link]), which is related to the covenant of promise. She is the mother of the New Testament believers, who are not slaves under law but sons under grace. We, the New Testament believers, are all born of her from above and will all be in the New Jerusalem in the new heaven and new earth.

verse.text: For it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"Rejoice, barren one who does not bear; break forth and shout, you who are not travailing, because [note]1[/note]many are the children of her who is [note]2[/note]desolate rather than of her who has her husband."
verse.note: This indicates that Abraham's spiritual descendants, who belong to the heavenly Jerusalem, to the covenant of promise under the freedom of grace, are far more numerous than his natural descendants, who belong to the earthly Jerusalem, to the covenant of law under the slavery of the law.
Denoting a woman without a husband; hence, a desolate one.

verse.text: But you, brothers, in the way [xref]a[/xref]Isaac was, are [note]1[/note]children of [xref]b[/xref]promise.
verse.note: Children of promise are children born of the heavenly Jerusalem through grace under the covenant of promise.

verse.text: But just as at that time he who was born [note]1[/note]according to the [xref]a[/xref]flesh [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]persecuted him [i]who was born[/i] [note]1[/note]according to the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]Spirit, [xref]d[/xref]so [note]4[/note]also [i]it is[/i] now.
verse.note: The two kinds of children brought forth by the two covenants are different in their natures. Those brought forth by the covenant of law are born according to the flesh; those brought forth by the covenant of promise are born according to the Spirit. The children born according to the flesh have no right to participate in God's promised blessing, but the children born according to the Spirit have the full right. The Judaizers were children of the former kind; the believers in Christ are of the latter kind. For [i]flesh[/i] and [i]Spirit,[/i] see notes [link]3[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 3[/link] and [link chapter="5"]19[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].
This indicates that Ishmael persecuted Isaac ([link]Gen. 21:9[/link]).
The children of promise ([link]v. 28[/link]) are born according to the Spirit, God's Spirit of life, who is the very blessing of God's promise to Abraham ([link]3:14[/link]).
The Judaizers, the descendants of Abraham according to the flesh, persecuted the believers, the descendants of Abraham according to the Spirit, as Ishmael persecuted Isaac.
