verse.text: But what does the Scripture say? [xref]a[/xref]"Cast out the [xref]b[/xref]maidservant and her son, for the [note]1[/note]son of the maidservant shall by [xref]c[/xref]no means inherit with the [note]2[/note]son of the [xref]d[/xref]free woman."
verse.note: The Judaizers, who are under the slavery of the law, are the sons of the maidservant. They shall by no means inherit God's promised blessing — the all-inclusive Spirit as the ultimate expression of the processed Triune God.
The New Testament believers, who are under the freedom of grace, are the sons of the free woman. They shall inherit the promised blessing of the Spirit.

verse.text: So then, brothers, we are [note]1[/note]not children of the maidservant but [xref]a[/xref]of the free woman.
verse.note: We, the believers in Christ, are not children of the law under the slavery of the law but children of grace under the freedom of grace to enjoy the all-inclusive Spirit with all the riches of Christ.

verse.text: It is for [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]freedom [i]that[/i] Christ has set us free; [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]stand fast therefore, and do not be [note]3[/note]entangled with a [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]yoke of [xref]d[/xref]slavery again.
verse.note: Freedom from the slavery of the law. Christ has set us free through His redeeming death and life-imparting resurrection that we may enjoy this freedom in grace.
I.e., stand fast in the freedom from the slavery of the law, not deviating from Christ, not falling from grace.
Or, held in a snare. To deviate from Christ to the law is to be entangled or held in a snare.
The yoke of slavery is the bondage of the law, which makes the law keepers slaves under a binding yoke.

verse.text: Behold, I Paul say to you that if you become [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]circumcised, Christ will profit you [note]2[/note]nothing.
verse.note: The Judaizers, the false brothers, made circumcision a condition of salvation ([link]2:3-5[/link]; [link]Acts 15:1[/link]). See note [link]3[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

If the Galatian believers had received circumcision, making it a condition of salvation, Christ would have profited them nothing, because by going back to the law they would have spontaneously relinquished Christ.

verse.text: And I testify again to every man who becomes [xref]a[/xref]circumcised that he is a debtor to do the whole law.
You have been [note]1[/note]brought to nought, [i]separated[/i] from Christ, you who are being justified by [xref]a[/xref]law; you have [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]fallen from [xref]c[/xref]grace.
verse.note: I.e., reduced to nothing, separated from Christ; deprived of all profit from Christ and so separated from Him (Darby's New Translation), making Him of no effect. To go back to the law is to be severed from Christ, to be brought to nought, separated from Christ.
To be brought to nought, separated from Christ, is to fall from grace. This implies that the grace in which we believers are is just Christ.

verse.text: For we [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]by the Spirit [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]out of faith [xref]c[/xref]eagerly await the [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]hope of [xref]e[/xref]righteousness.
verse.note: In contrast to [i]by the flesh[/i] ([link]3:3[/link]).
In contrast to [i]out of the works of law[/i] ([link]3:2[/link]).
The righteousness we hope for, which is Christ Himself ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]). It is not in the flesh out of the works of law but in the Spirit out of faith.

verse.text: For [xref]a[/xref]in Christ Jesus neither [xref]b[/xref]circumcision [note]1[/note]avails anything nor uncircumcision, but [xref]c[/xref]faith [i]avails,[/i] [note]2[/note]operating through [note]3[/note]love.
verse.note: I.e., has any force, any practical power.

Living faith is active. It operates through love to work out the fulfillment of the law ([link]v. 14[/link]). Circumcision is simply an outward ordinance, having no power of life. Hence, it avails nothing. Faith receives the Spirit of life ([link]3:2[/link]); thus, it is full of power. It operates through love to fulfill not only the law but also God's purpose, that is, to complete the sonship of God for His corporate expression — the Body of Christ.

Love is related to our appreciation of Christ. Without such an appreciation, faith cannot operate. The hearing of faith awakens our loving appreciation, and the more we love the Lord, the more faith operates to bring us into the riches, the profit, of the all-inclusive Spirit.

verse.text: You were [xref]a[/xref]running well. [xref]b[/xref]Who hindered you that you would not believe and obey the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]truth?
verse.note: Not the doctrine but the reality in Christ, as preached to the Galatians by the apostle.

verse.text: This [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]persuasion is not of Him who [xref]b[/xref]calls you.
verse.note: The Judaizers' persuasive teaching, which distracted the Galatians away from Christ to the observances of the law.

verse.text: A little [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]leaven leavens the [note]1[/note]whole lump.
verse.note: [i]Leaven[/i] refers to the false teachings of the Judaizers (cf. [link]Matt. 16:12[/link]), and [i]the whole lump,[/i] to all the believers collectively, the church.

verse.text: I am [xref]a[/xref]confident in the Lord concerning you that you will be [xref]b[/xref]of no other mind; but he who is [xref]c[/xref]troubling you shall bear the judgment, whoever he may be.

But I, brothers, if I still preach [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]circumcision, why am I still being [xref]b[/xref]persecuted? Then the [xref]c[/xref]stumbling block of the [note]1[/note]cross has been annulled.
verse.note: Circumcision foreshadowed the dealing with man's flesh; the cross is the reality of that dealing ([link]Col. 2:11-12[/link]). The Judaizers endeavored to bring the Galatians back to the shadow; the apostle Paul struggled to keep them in the reality.

verse.text: I wish that those [xref]a[/xref]upsetting you would even [note]1[/note]cut themselves off.
verse.note: The apostle Paul wished that the Judaizers who upset the Galatians by insisting on circumcision would cut off not only their own foreskin but even themselves. Their upsetting, disturbing self needed to be amputated.

verse.text: For you were [xref]a[/xref]called for [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]freedom, brothers; only do not [xref]c[/xref][i]turn[/i] this [xref]d[/xref]freedom into an opportunity for the [note]2[/note]flesh, but through [xref]e[/xref]love [note]3[/note][xref]f[/xref]serve one another.
verse.note: Freedom without limitation always results in the indulgence of the flesh. Freedom with limitation leads us to love others and, through love, to serve them as slaves (cf. [link]v. 14[/link]).
See note [link]3[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].
Lit., serve as a slave.

verse.text: For the whole [xref]a[/xref]law is fulfilled in one word, in this, [xref]b[/xref]"You shall love your neighbor as yourself."
But if you bite and devour one another, beware lest you be consumed by one another.
But I say, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Walk [xref]b[/xref]by the [note]2[/note]Spirit and you shall by no means [xref]c[/xref]fulfill the [xref]d[/xref]lust of the [note]2[/note]flesh.
verse.note: The Greek word here means [i]to tread all around, to walk at large;[/i] hence, to deport oneself, move, and act in ordinary daily life, implying a common, habitual daily walk (cf. [link]Rom. 6:4[/link]; [link]8:4[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:17-18[/link]).

According to the context of the chapter, the Spirit here must be the Holy Spirit, who dwells in and mingles with our regenerated spirit. To walk by the Spirit is to have our walk regulated by the Holy Spirit from within our spirit. This is in contrast to having our walk regulated by the law in the realm of our flesh. See note [link]3[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].[br][br]The flesh is the uttermost expression of the fallen tripartite man ([link]Gen. 6:3[/link]), and the Spirit is the ultimate realization of the processed Triune God ([link]John 7:39[/link]). Because of Christ's redemption and the Spirit's work of regeneration, we who have received God's dispensing can walk by the Spirit, by the processed Triune God, instead of by the flesh, by our fallen being. Paul wrote this book not only to rescue the distracted Galatian believers from the law, on the negative side, but also, on the positive side, to bring them into the realization that the believers have the all-inclusive life-giving Spirit in their spirit that they may live, walk, and have their being in this Spirit.

verse.text: For the [note]1[/note]flesh lusts [xref]a[/xref]against the [note]2[/note]Spirit, and the Spirit against the flesh; for these [note]3[/note]oppose each other that you would not do the things that you [xref]b[/xref]desire.
verse.note: For [i]the flesh[/i] and [i]the Spirit,[/i] see notes [link]3[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 3[/link] and [link chapter="5"]19[sup]1[/sup][/link][/link] and [link chapter="5"]22[sup]1[/sup][/link] in this chapter.
See note [link]16[sup]2[/sup][/link].
See note [link]23[sup]2[/sup] in Rom. 7[/link].

verse.text: But if you are [xref]a[/xref]led by the [note]1[/note]Spirit, you are [xref]b[/xref]not under the [note]1[/note]law.
verse.note: The law is related to our flesh ([link]Rom. 7:5[/link]), and our flesh is against the Spirit ([link]v. 17[/link]). Hence, the Spirit is in contrast to the law. When we walk by the Spirit, who is in our regenerated spirit, we will not fulfill the lusts of our flesh ([link]v. 16[/link]); when we are led by the Spirit, we are not under the law. The Spirit of life, not the law of letters, is our guiding principle, regulating our Christian walk in our regenerated spirit.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]works of the flesh are manifest, which are such things as [note]2[/note]fornication, uncleanness, lasciviousness,
verse.note: The flesh is the expression of the old Adam. The fallen life of the old Adam is expressed practically in the flesh, and the works of the flesh, such as those listed in [link]vv. 19-21[/link], are different aspects of such a fleshly expression. Fornication, uncleanness, lasciviousness, bouts of drunkenness, and carousings are related to the lust of the corrupted body. Enmities, strife, jealousy, outbursts of anger, factions, divisions, sects, and envyings are related to the fallen soul, which is very closely related to the corrupted body. Idolatry and sorcery are related to the deadened spirit. This proves that the three parts of our fallen being — body, soul, and spirit — are all involved with the corrupted, evil flesh.
Fornication, uncleanness, and lasciviousness are of one group, concerning evil passions.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Idolatry, [xref]a[/xref]sorcery, [note]2[/note]enmities, [xref]b[/xref]strife, jealousy, outbursts of anger, [note]3[/note]factions, [xref]c[/xref]divisions, [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]sects,
verse.note: Idolatry and sorcery are of one group, concerning demonic worship.
Enmities, strife, jealousy, and outbursts of anger are of one group, concerning evil moods.
Factions, divisions, sects, and envyings are of one group, concerning parties.
The same Greek word as for [i]heresies[/i] in [link]2 Pet. 2:1[/link]. Here it refers to schools of opinion (Darby's New Translation), or sects.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Envyings, [note]1[/note]bouts of drunkenness, carousings, and things like these, of which I tell you beforehand, even as I have said before, that those who practice such things will [xref]b[/xref]not [note]2[/note]inherit the kingdom of God.
verse.note: Bouts of drunkenness and carousings are of one group, concerning dissipation.

The inheritance of the kingdom of God refers to the enjoyment of the coming kingdom as a reward to the overcoming believers. It is not the same as a believer's salvation; rather, it is a reward in addition to the believer's salvation. See notes [link]5[sup]3[/sup] in Eph. 5[/link] and [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 12[/link].

verse.text: But the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fruit of the Spirit is [xref]b[/xref]love, [xref]c[/xref]joy, [xref]d[/xref]peace, long-suffering, kindness, goodness, faithfulness,
verse.note: What the flesh does is works without life ([link]v. 19[/link]); what the Spirit brings forth is fruit full of life. Only nine items of the fruit of the Spirit, as different expressions of the Spirit, who is life within us, are listed as illustrations here. The fruit of the Spirit includes additional items, such as lowliness ([link]Eph. 4:2[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:3[/link]), compassion ([link]Phil. 2:1[/link]), godliness ([link]2 Pet. 1:6[/link]), righteousness ([link]Rom. 14:17[/link]; [link]Eph. 5:9[/link]), holiness ([link]Eph. 1:4[/link]; [link]Col. 1:22[/link]), and purity ([link]Matt. 5:8[/link]). In both [link]Eph. 4:2[/link] and [link]Col. 3:12[/link], lowliness is mentioned as a virtue in addition to meekness, which is listed here. In [link]Rom. 14:17[/link] righteousness, peace, and joy are all aspects of the kingdom of God today. But only peace and joy, not righteousness, are listed here. In [link]2 Pet. 1:5-7[/link] godliness and endurance are counted with self-control and love as characteristics of spiritual growth, but they are not listed here. In [link]Matt. 5:5-9[/link] righteousness, mercy, and purity are reckoned with meekness and peace as the requirement of the reality of the kingdom today. However, none of the three virtues is named here.[br][br]As the flesh is the expression of the old Adam, so the Spirit is the realization of Christ. Christ is actually lived out as the Spirit. The items of the fruit of the Spirit listed here are the very characteristics of Christ.

verse.text: Meekness, [xref]a[/xref]self-control; against such things there is [xref]b[/xref]no law.
[note]1[/note]But they who are [xref]a[/xref]of Christ Jesus [note]2[/note]have [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]crucified the [xref]c[/xref]flesh with its passions and its lusts.
verse.note: [i]But[/i] in [link]v. 22[/link] introduces a contrast between the fruit of the Spirit in that verse and the works of the flesh in [link]v. 19[/link], whereas [i]but[/i] in this verse introduces a contrast between the crucifying of the flesh here and the works of the flesh in [link]v. 19[/link].

The crucifixion of the old man in [link]Rom. 6:6[/link] and the crucifixion of the "I" in [link]Gal. 2:20[/link] were not accomplished by us. But here it says that we have crucified the flesh with its passions and its lusts. The old man and the "I" are our being; the flesh is the expression of our being in our practical living. The crucifixion of our old man and the "I" is a fact accomplished by Christ on the cross, whereas the crucifying of our flesh with its passions and its lusts is our practical experience of the fact. This practical experience must be carried out through the Spirit by our executing of the crucifixion that Christ accomplished. This is to put to death by the Spirit the practices of our lustful body with its evil members ([link]Rom. 8:13b[/link]; [link]Col. 3:5[/link]).[br][br]There are three aspects of the experience of the cross: (1) the fact accomplished by Christ ([link]Rom. 6:6[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:20[/link]); (2) our application of the accomplished fact ([link]v. 24[/link]); and (3) our experience of what we have applied, by bearing the cross daily ([link]Matt. 16:24[/link]; [link]Luke 9:23[/link]).

This book unveils that the law misused is in opposition to Christ ([link]2:16[/link]) and that the flesh lusts against the Spirit ([link]v. 17[/link]). The cross has nullified the "I," which inclines to keep the law ([link]2:20[/link]), and the flesh, which lusts against the Spirit, that Christ may replace the law and the Spirit may replace the flesh. God does not want us to keep the law by the flesh; He wants us to live Christ by the Spirit.

verse.text: If we [note]1[/note]live by the Spirit, let us also [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]walk by the Spirit.
verse.note: To live by the Spirit is to have our life dependent on and regulated by the Spirit, not by the law. This equals the walk by the Spirit in [link]v. 16[/link] but differs from the walk by the Spirit in this verse (see note 2).

Lit., walk according to rules. The Greek word means [i]to observe the elements, to walk according to the elements,[/i] e.g., to walk in line, to march in military rank, to keep in step; and, derivatively, to walk in an orderly, regulated manner (cf. [link]6:16[/link]; [link]Acts 21:24[/link]; [link]Rom. 4:12[/link] and note; [link]Phil. 3:16[/link] and note 4).[br][br]Both the walk in [link]v. 16[/link] and the walk in this verse are by the Spirit and are regulated by the Spirit. The former refers to a general, daily walk; the latter, to a walk that takes God's unique goal as the direction and purpose of life, and a walk that follows the Spirit as the elementary rule, the basic principle. Such a walk is cultivated by living in the new creation ([link]6:16[/link] and note 2), by pursuing Christ in order to gain Him ([link]Phil. 3:12[/link] and notes), and by practicing the church life ([link]Rom. 12:1-5[/link]; [link]Eph. 4:1-16[/link]), thus fulfilling God's intention in Christ for the church.

verse.text: Let us [note]1[/note]not become [xref]a[/xref]vainglorious, provoking one another, [xref]b[/xref]envying one another.
verse.note: This is the result of the walk by the Spirit in [link]v. 25[/link]. Vainglory, provoking, and envying are all of the flesh (cf. [link]v. 24[/link]). Vainglory gives rise to provoking and envying. If we by the Spirit slay vainglory, provoking and envying will be terminated automatically, resulting in peace. These three matters test in a very practical way whether we are walking by the Spirit.

verse.text: Brothers, even if a man is overtaken in some offense, you who are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spiritual [xref]b[/xref]restore such a one in a [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]spirit of [xref]d[/xref]meekness, looking to yourself lest you also be [xref]e[/xref]tempted.
verse.note: I.e., living and walking by the Spirit ([link]5:25[/link]).
Our regenerated spirit, indwelt by and mingled with the Holy Spirit. A spirit of meekness is the issue of living and walking by the Spirit, as mentioned in [link]5:16[/link], [link]25[/link].

verse.text: Bear one another's burdens, and in this way you will fulfill the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]law of Christ completely.
verse.note: The higher and better law of life, which works through love ([link]Rom. 8:2[/link]; [link]John 13:34[/link]). Love is the issue and expression of the divine life (cf. [link]1 Cor. 13[/link]) and is an item of the fruit of the Spirit ([link]5:22[/link]). The law of Christ, which is the law of love, must be substantiated by the law of the Spirit of life that we may be able to bear one another's burdens.

verse.text: For if anyone [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]thinks he is something when he is nothing, he [xref]b[/xref]deceives himself.
verse.note: Those who think of themselves as something will not bear the burdens of others. Only those who do not regard themselves as anything will bear others' burdens as a spontaneous result of walking in and by the Spirit.

verse.text: But let each man [xref]a[/xref]prove his own work, and then he will have his boast in regard to himself alone and not in regard to another.
For each one shall bear his own load.
But let him who is instructed in the word [xref]a[/xref]share in all [note]1[/note]good things with him who instructs.
verse.note: Things that are good for this life, the necessities of daily living.

verse.text: Do not be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]deceived: God is not [xref]b[/xref]mocked; for whatever a man [xref]c[/xref]sows, this he will also reap.
verse.note: This refers again to the Judaizers' false teachings, which caused the Galatians to deviate from the Spirit in their spirit to the keeping of the law by their flesh.

verse.text: For he who sows [note]1[/note]unto his own [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]flesh will [xref]b[/xref]reap [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]corruption of the flesh, but he who [xref]d[/xref]sows [note]1[/note]unto the [note]2[/note][xref]e[/xref]Spirit will [xref]f[/xref]of the Spirit reap [note]3[/note][xref]g[/xref]eternal life.
verse.note: With a view to, or, for. To sow unto one's own flesh is to sow for one's own flesh, with the desire and purpose of the flesh in view, to fulfill what the flesh covets. To sow unto the Spirit is to sow for the Spirit, with the desire and aim of the Spirit in view, to accomplish what the Spirit desires. Everything we do is a sowing either unto our own flesh or unto the Spirit, and all our sowing issues in a reaping either of corruption out of the flesh or of eternal life out of the Spirit.
See notes [link]3[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 3[/link], and [link chapter="5"]19[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

To sow for the fulfilling of the purpose of the flesh issues in corruption; to sow for the accomplishing of the aim of the Spirit issues in life, even eternal life. Corruption is of the flesh, indicating that the flesh is corrupted; eternal life is of the Spirit and is the Spirit Himself.

verse.text: And let us [xref]a[/xref]not lose heart in doing what is good, for in the proper season we will reap if we [note]1[/note]do not [xref]b[/xref]faint.
verse.note: Lit., are not relaxed.

verse.text: So then, as we have the opportunity, let us do what is [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]good toward all, but especially toward those of the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]household of the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]faith.
verse.note: This refers mainly to the ministering of material things to the needy ([link]2 Cor. 9:6-9[/link]).

[i]The household of the faith[/i] refers to the children of promise ([link]4:28[/link]), all who are sons of God through faith in Christ ([link]3:26[/link]). All the believers in Christ together constitute a universal household, the great family of God. This is through faith in Christ, not through the works of law. This household, as the new man ([link]Col. 3:10-11[/link]), is composed of all the members of Christ, with Christ as their constituent. Hence, we should do good, especially toward those of this household, regardless of their race and social rank ([link]3:28[/link]).
See note [link]23[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: See with what [note]1[/note]large letters I have written to you with my [xref]a[/xref]own hand.
verse.note: Perhaps this was because of the disease in Paul's eyes ([link]4:13-15[/link] and note [link]15[sup]2[/sup][/link] there).

verse.text: As many as desire to make a [note]1[/note]good show [note]2[/note]in the flesh, these compel you to be [xref]a[/xref]circumcised, [i]but[/i] only that they may not be [xref]b[/xref]persecuted for the [xref]c[/xref]cross of Christ.
verse.note: Lit., good countenance; hence, good appearance for making a good show, a fair display. It is used here in a negative sense.[br][br]Circumcision, like the cross, is not a good show but an abasement. However, the Judaizers made it a good show as a boast in the flesh ([link]v. 13[/link]).

I.e., outwardly in the sphere of the flesh, which is condemned and repudiated by God. To be in the flesh is to be in our natural and external being without the inward reality and spiritual value that are in our regenerated spirit.

verse.text: For neither do they that become circumcised [xref]a[/xref]keep the law themselves, but they desire you to be circumcised that they may boast [xref]b[/xref]in your flesh.

But far be it from me to [xref]a[/xref]boast except in the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, through [note]2[/note]whom the [note]3[/note]world has been [xref]c[/xref]crucified to me and I to the world.
verse.note: The cross was truly an abasement, but the apostle made it his boast.
The world has been crucified to us and we to the world. This has taken place not directly but through Christ, who was crucified.

The next verse, being an explanation of this verse, proves that the world here is mainly the religious world. In this book Paul dealt with religious people who were concerned for the things of God but who were misguided and were in error and whose religion had become a world. By the cross we are separated from the religious world and are thus qualified to live in the new creation.

verse.text: For neither is [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]circumcision anything nor uncircumcision, but a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]new creation [i]is what matters.[/i]
verse.note: The old creation is our old man in Adam ([link]Eph. 4:22[/link]), our natural being by birth, without God's life and the divine nature. The new creation is the new man in Christ ([link]Eph. 4:24[/link]), our being that is regenerated by the Spirit ([link]John 3:6[/link]), having God's life and the divine nature wrought into it ([link]John 3:36[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 1:4[/link]), having Christ as its constituent ([link]Col. 3:10-11[/link]), and having become a new constitution. This refers to the nature, the inward and intrinsic organic constituent, of the church. Thus, the new creation is composed of sons; it is a corporate, divine sonship ([link]3:26[/link]; [link]4:5[/link], [link]7[/link]) brought forth through Christ's redemption, the Spirit's regeneration, and God's dispensing of Himself into us, and through our entering collectively as this new man into an organic union with the Triune God.[br][br]The old creation was old because it did not have God's element; the new creation is new because it has God as its element. Although we are still the old creation, we experience the reality of the new creation when we walk according to the Spirit ([link]5:16[/link], [link]25[/link]). The main issue in this book is that we are the new creation and that we should live by the new creation through an organic union with the Triune God. This new creation fulfills God's eternal purpose, which is to express Himself in His sonship.[br][br]Circumcision is an ordinance of the law; the new creation is the masterpiece of life with the divine nature. The former is of dead letters; the latter is of the living Spirit. Hence, the new creation is what matters. This book exposes the impotence of both the law and circumcision. The law cannot impart life ([link]3:21[/link]) to regenerate us, and circumcision cannot energize us ([link]5:6[/link]) to live a new creation. But the Son of God, who has been revealed in us ([link]1:16[/link]), can enliven us and make us a new creation, and Christ, who lives in us ([link]2:20[/link]), can afford us the riches of His life that we may live the new creation. The law has been replaced by Christ ([link]2:19-20[/link]), and circumcision has been fulfilled by Christ's crucifixion ([link]v. 14[/link]). Hence, neither circumcision nor uncircumcision is anything, but a new creation with Christ as its life is what matters. To be the new creation is the reason for and result of sowing unto the Spirit ([link]v. 8[/link]). The keeping of the law and the practicing of circumcision are a sowing unto the flesh; they do not change the old creation. But sowing unto the Spirit makes us a new creation, which is re-created by the Spirit, transformed by the divine life, and constituted with the rich element of the processed Triune God by His mingling of Himself with us.

verse.text: And as many as [note]1[/note]walk by this [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]rule, [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]peace be upon them and mercy, even upon the [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]Israel of God.
verse.note: See note [link]25[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

The rule of being a new creation, of living by the Spirit through faith, having the Triune God as our life and living, in contrast to keeping the law by observing ordinances. To walk by this rule is to walk by the Spirit ([link]5:25[/link]).

Paul opened this book with grace and peace ([link]1:3[/link]), but he ended it with the mentioning of peace before mercy and grace ([link]v. 18[/link]). Peace is the condition that results from grace. As we abide in a peaceful condition, we need to continue receiving mercy and grace.

I.e., the real Israel ([link]Rom. 9:6b[/link]; [link]2:28-29[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:3[/link]), including all the Gentile and Jewish believers in Christ, who are the true sons of Abraham ([link]Gal. 3:7[/link], [link]29[/link]), who are the household of the faith ([link]v. 10[/link]), and who are those in the new creation. They walk by "this rule," express God's image, and execute God's authority, and are typified by Jacob, who was transformed into Israel, a prince of God and a victor ([link]Gen. 32:27-28[/link]).

verse.text: Henceforth let no one trouble me, for I bear in my body the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]brands of Jesus.
verse.note: The marks branded on slaves to indicate their owners. With Paul, a slave of Christ ([link]Rom. 1:1[/link]), the brands were physically the scars of his wounds received in his faithful service to his Master ([link]2 Cor. 11:23-27[/link]). Spiritually, they signify the characteristics of the life that he lived, a life like the one the Lord Jesus lived on this earth. Such a life is continually crucified ([link]John 12:24[/link]), does the will of God ([link]John 6:38[/link]), does not seek its own glory but the glory of God ([link]John 7:18[/link]), and is submissive and obedient to God, even unto the death of the cross ([link]Phil. 2:8[/link]). The apostle followed the pattern of the Lord Jesus, bearing the brands, the characteristics of His life. In this he was absolutely different from the Judaizers.

verse.text: The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your [note]2[/note]spirit, [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]brothers. Amen.
verse.note: The grace of Jesus Christ is the bountiful supply of the Triune God (who is embodied in the Son and realized as the life-giving Spirit) enjoyed by us through the exercise of our human spirit.

Our regenerated spirit indwelt by the Spirit, who is the focus of God's promised blessing stressed so much throughout this book. It is in this spirit of ours that we experience and enjoy the Spirit as the central blessing of the New Testament. Hence, we need the grace of the Lord, which is the bountiful supply of the all-inclusive Spirit ([link]Phil. 1:19[/link]), to be with our spirit.[br][br]Christ, the Spirit, the new creation, and our spirit are the four basic items revealed in this book as the underlying thought of God's economy. Christ is the center of God's economy, and the Spirit is the reality of Christ. When Christ is realized through the Spirit in our spirit, we become the new creation. Hence, our spirit is vital for us to live the life of the new creation for the fulfilling of God's purpose.[br][br]This book places strong emphasis on the cross and the experience of crucifixion, in order to deal with the negative items, such as the law, the flesh, the "I," the religious world, slavery, and the curse, thereby bringing in the positive items that are revealed in this book: Christ, the Spirit, the sons of God, the heirs of promise, the household of the faith, the new creation, and the Israel of God. The summarizing thought in this book is that through the cross of Christ the law, the flesh, and religion are terminated that we may obtain the Spirit, the new creation, and our spirit, that through the Spirit, who is the realization of Christ, we may be the new creation in our spirit, bearing the brands of Jesus, and that we may enjoy the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ in our spirit.

The rebuked foolish Galatians ([link]3:1[/link]) had already been addressed with this intimate term a number of times ([link]1:11[/link]; [link]3:15[/link]; [link]4:12[/link], [link]28[/link], [link]31[/link]; [link]5:11[/link], [link]13[/link]; [link]6:1[/link]). At the close of such a severe, rebuking, and warning Epistle, the apostle used this loving term again, placing it particularly at the end of the sentence, to express his unchanging love toward them, assuring them that they were still his brothers in the household of the faith ([link]v. 10[/link]).
